fullDescription:
The Biographer of Heroes - Philosopher and Comparative Historian

Plutarch of Chaeronea (c. 46-120 CE) stands as one of antiquity's greatest biographers and moral philosophers. His Parallel Lives paired Greek and Roman heroes to illuminate virtue and vice across cultures, while his vast Moralia explored topics ranging from Greek religious practices to Egyptian theology, from the nature of oracles to the decline of divine worship. As a priest at Delphi and a man deeply versed in both Greek and Roman traditions, Plutarch offers an unparalleled window into the religious world of the ancient Mediterranean.

Life and Career

Born in Chaeronea, Boeotia (the same region as Hesiod), Plutarch came from a distinguished family. He studied philosophy at Athens under Ammonius and traveled widely throughout the Roman Empire, including visits to Alexandria and Rome itself. Despite his cosmopolitan education, he remained devoted to his hometown, serving as archon and later as a priest of Apollo at the nearby sanctuary of Delphi, where he served for the last thirty years of his life.

Plutarch's position at Delphi gave him intimate knowledge of Greek religious traditions at a crucial historical moment - when traditional paganism faced both internal transformation and external challenges. His dialogues on the oracle's decline and the nature of divination preserve invaluable testimony about Greek religious consciousness in the Roman Imperial period.

Plutarch's most famous work pairs Greek and Roman heroes for comparative moral study. The surviving pairs include:

- Theseus and Romulus (founders)
- Alexander and Caesar (conquerors)
- Demosthenes and Cicero (orators)
- Pericles and Fabius Maximus (statesmen)
- Alcibiades and Coriolanus (brilliant but flawed leaders)

For mythological studies, the Lives are invaluable because Plutarch treats legendary figures like Theseus and Romulus with the same biographical method as historical figures. His Life of Theseus preserves numerous variants of the Athenian hero's mythology, while the Life of Romulus documents Rome's foundation myths. Plutarch explicitly discusses how to extract historical truth from mythological narrative.

Moralia - Religious and Philosophical Treatises

The Moralia comprises over 60 essays on diverse subjects. For the study of ancient religion and mythology, the most significant include:

De Iside et Osiride (On Isis and Osiris)
Plutarch's most important mythological treatise provides the fullest ancient Greek account of Egyptian religion. He narrates the myth of Osiris, Set, and Isis, then interprets it through Greek philosophical frameworks. This work demonstrates ancient comparative mythology, as Plutarch identifies Egyptian deities with Greek counterparts and seeks universal religious truths behind diverse traditions.

De Pythiae Oraculis (On the Pythian Oracle)
A dialogue set at Delphi examining why the Pythia no longer speaks in verse. Plutarch explores the nature of divine inspiration, the mechanics of prophecy, and the relationship between the god Apollo and his human medium.

De Defectu Oraculorum (On the Decline of Oracles)
This profound dialogue addresses why so many oracles have fallen silent. Plutarch's speakers debate whether this reflects divine withdrawal, demographic decline, or cosmic cycles. The work introduces his famous theory of daimones - intermediate spirits between gods and humans who animate oracles.

De Sera Numinis Vindicta (On the Delays of Divine Vengeance)
A theodicy addressing why the gods do not immediately punish wrongdoers. Plutarch develops sophisticated arguments about divine justice, reincarnation, and the moral order of the cosmos.

De Superstitione (On Superstition)
Plutarch distinguishes between proper religious reverence and degraded superstition, providing insight into ancient debates about authentic versus corrupt worship.

Quaestiones Graecae and Quaestiones Romanae
These works explain the origins of Greek and Roman religious customs, preserving countless details about rituals, festivals, and cult practices.

Theological and Philosophical Contributions

Plutarch was a Platonist who believed in a transcendent supreme deity, intermediate divine beings (daimones), and the immortality of the soul. His religious philosophy represents a 'Middle Platonism' that would influence later Neoplatonism and early Christianity. Key ideas include:

- The distinction between the supreme God and lesser deities
- Daimones as intermediaries who operate oracles and interact with humans
- The survival and reincarnation of souls
- The interpretation of myths as philosophical allegories
- The unity underlying diverse religious traditions

Legacy

Plutarch's influence on Western culture is incalculable. Shakespeare drew extensively from the Lives for his Roman plays. The founding fathers of the American republic read Plutarch for models of civic virtue. His Moralia preserved religious and philosophical knowledge that would otherwise be lost. For the study of ancient mythology, Plutarch remains indispensable - not only for the information he preserves but for his sophisticated hermeneutic approach to interpreting mythological traditions.
